summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of New Mexico today entered a final judgment against Albuquerque, New Mexico-based SMP Properties, LLC and Michael Pack, the owner and manager of SMP, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Albuquerque, N.M., on March 1, 2003, SMP and Pack agreed to a judgment that permanently restrains the value of the property and reserves the right to apply for an inverse condemnation.  The court also granted SMP's motion for summary judgment on the other side of the issue, ordering SMP to pay $143,850 in pre-judgment interest and a civil penalty of $150,000.  SMP agreed to settle the case by consenting to the entry of a judgment without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the District of Albuquerque today announced criminal charges against Pack.   The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted in the New Mexico Office by Michael J. Klopping and supervised by Jennifer C. Barry. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in this matter. Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can quickly and easily check the backgrounds of people selling investments by using theÂ SEC's investor.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â In a related case, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Pack on February 28, 2012, charging SMP with violating Section 42A-1-26 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 42a-3 thereunder, and with aiding and abetting SMP’s violations of Section 9(a) of Exchange Act Rule 9b2-1 thereunder and Exchange Act Rules 9b-20, 13a-1, 13b-11, and 12b-13 thereunder in violation of Section 17(a)(1) of Securities Act Section 9 of the Exchange Act.  Without admitting or abetting these violations, Smp and Pack consented to the issuance of the final judgment permanently enjoining each of them from violating Section 9 and Rule 9a-10 thereunder; and ordering Pack to pay disgorgement and prejudgment interest in the amount of $157,472
